chapter: Stridor and Congenital Conditions of Larynx

questions.question: Question 1: Inspiratory stridor is found in what kind of lesions:
questions.explanation:
Inspiratory stridor is seen in supraglottic lesions. It is often produced in obstructive lesions of 
supraglottis or pharynx, e.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess. 534 
Sold by @itachibot Expiratory stridor is produced in lesions of thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi such 
as bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis. Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea like laryngeal 
papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis. Stridor is an audible respiratory noise that gets produced by turbulent airflow through an 
obstructed upper airway. It is an inspiratory sound that may have an expiratory component. It is 
distinct from stertor which is a snoring-like noise produced from an obstructed nasopharynx or 
oropharynx. The intensity and pitch of sounds originating from the respiratory system vary based on their site 
of origin within the respiratory tract and may be heard with or without a stethoscope. Usually, the 
pitch of the sound increases, and the intensity decreases as one goes lower into the respiratory 
tract.
questions.chapter_heading: Stridor and Congenital Conditions of Larynx

questions.question: Question 2: What is the most common cause of congenital stridor?
questions.explanation:
Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital cause of stridor. It is characterized by excessive flaccidity of the supraglottic larynx which is sucked in during 
inspiration producing stridor and sometimes cyanosis. It presents just after birth and subsides by 2 years of age. Stridor improves (decreases) in the 
prone position, worsens during feeding. The cry is normal. On examination, omega-shaped 
epiglottis is seen. 535 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Stridor and Congenital Conditions of Larynx

questions.question: Question 3: What is congenital laryngeal stridor also known as?
questions.explanation:
Laryngomalacia is also called congenital laryngeal stridor. It is the most common cause of stridor 
in newborns.
questions.chapter_heading: Stridor and Congenital Conditions of Larynx

questions.question:
Question 4: A 1-week old infant has been diagnosed to have laryngomalacia. Which of the following 
statements is false about this condition?

options.a: Most common cause of stridor in newborn

questions.explanation:
Laryngomalacia has an excellent prognosis. Laryngomalacia is the most common cause of stridor in newborns. It presents just after birth and subsides by 2 years of age. Stridor improves (decreases) in the 
prone position, worsens during feeding. The cry is normal. On examination, omega-shaped 
epiglottis is seen
questions.chapter_heading: Stridor and Congenital Conditions of Larynx

questions.question:
Question 5: A worried mother brings her 2-week old infant to you with complaints of noisy breathing that 
worsens during feeding. On direct laryngoscopy, the following is seen. What is the preferred 
treatment for this condition?
questions.explanation:
The clinical picture and omega-shaped epiglottis are suggestive of laryngomalacia. Conservative 
treatment is preferred for laryngomalacia as this condition self-corrects by two years of age. Tracheostomy may be required for some cases of severe respiratory obstruction. Supraglottoplasty 
is required in severe laryngomalacia. Signs of severe laryngomalacia include: • Difficulty feeding • Increased effort in breathing • Poor weight gain • Pauses in the breathing 536 
Sold by @itachibot • Frequent spitting up
questions.chapter_heading: Stridor and Congenital Conditions of Larynx

questions.question:
Question 6: A 5-year-old child is brought to you with complaints of noisy breathing. On performing direct 
laryngoscopy, subglottic stenosis is noted. Which grading system will you use to report the 
extent of the stenosis?
questions.explanation:
Myer Cotton’s grading is used for subglottic stenosis. It is the abnormal thickening of cricoid/fibrous tissue proliferation below cords. It causes the 
airway to narrow and presents with dyspnea, biphasic stridor and a normal cry. Diagnosis: • In full-term infants, subglottic diameter <4mm. • In premature infants, subglottic diameter <3mm. The Myer Cotton’s grading system allows to stratify the stenosis and plan for treatment: • Grade 1: <50% stenosis • Grade 2: 51-70% stenosis • Grade 3: 71-99% stenosis • Grade 4: No lumen detected Other options • Option A - Hyams grading is a predictive tool used in olfactory neuroblastoma. • Option B - House Brackmann grading is used as a facial nerve grading system. • Option D - Modified mallampati classification is used to assess difficult airway
questions.chapter_heading: Stridor and Congenital Conditions of Larynx

questions.question:
Question 7: A 45-year-old man presents to the ENT OPD with a swelling on the right side of his neck. The 
swelling moves with deglutition. On examination, the swelling is compressible and there is a 
gurgling sound heard on compression. What is his diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
On compressing the swelling, there is a gurgling/hissing sound known as Bryce’s sign. The given 
clinical picture with a positive Bryce sign is suggestive of laryngocele. Laryngocele is an air-filled cavity within the larynx developing from the saccule. The patient 
presents with a neck swelling that is soft and compressible. Options A: Branchial cleft cysts does not move with deglutition. Option C: Cystic hygroma does not move with deglutition and usually presents before 2 years. Option D: Thyroglossal cyst presents as a midline swelling.
questions.chapter_heading: Stridor and Congenital Conditions of Larynx

questions.question:
Question 8: You are the ENT resident performing a direct laryngoscopy procedure on a patient and report 
the presence of a laryngocele. The given condition is due to an enlarged diverticulum from 
which part of the larynx?
questions.explanation:
Laryngocele arises from the saccule of the ventricle. It is an abnormal dilation of the laryngeal 
saccule and extends beyond the thyroid cartilage and the ventricle. 537 
Sold by @itachibot It is seen in trumpet players, glass-blowers, or weight lifters due to raised transglottic air pressure. 
It can be internal, external, or combined. External laryngocele presents as a reducible swelling in 
the neck which increases in size on coughing or performing Valsalva maneuver. Internal laryngocele is managed by marsupialization. External laryngocele is managed by excision 
(external/LASER).
questions.chapter_heading: Stridor and Congenital Conditions of Larynx

questions.question:
Question 9: A mother brings her 4-month-old infant to the ENT department with complaints of difficulty 
in breathing. On examination, you notice biphasic stridor. Rigid bronchoscopy shows 
subglottic hemangioma. Which of the following is not included in the treatment of this 
condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical picture is of congenital subglottic hemangioma. Embolization is not preferred in 
congenital laryngeal conditions. All congenital laryngeal conditions tend to regress with growth. The principal management is conservative as many hemangiomas involute 
spontaneously. Depending on the status of the airway, treatment can involve: • To wait and watch • Steroid therapy • Tracheostomy and observation If the condition does not regress with time, the modalities of treatment include: • LASER excision • Laryngofissure and excision • -pexy and -plasty procedures (epiglottopexy, supraglottoplasty, etc)
questions.chapter_heading: Stridor and Congenital Conditions of Larynx

questions.question:
Question 10: A 30-year-old singer complains of a change in her voice. Direct laryngoscopy procedure shows 
the presence of laryngeal cysts. Which part of the larynx does the cyst arise from? 532 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Laryngeal cysts arise in the aryepiglottic folds. 538 
Sold by @itachibot These are benign conditions that need no intervention unless they are large. Large cysts can cause 
airway obstruction/change in voice. These require immediate aspiration followed by deroofing.
questions.chapter_heading: Stridor and Congenital Conditions of Larynx

questions.question: Question 11: Identify the lesion of vocal cord in the image given below :
questions.explanation:
The image showing grape-like projections, involving the anterior part of the vocal cords depicts 
a laryngeal papilloma. Laryngeal papilloma is a benign tumor of the larynx caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV 
type 6 and 11). They can occur in children, most commonly around 3 -5 years of age (juvenile 
papillomatosis), as well as in adults. They involve the supraglottic and glottic regions of the 
larynx. Seeding of the lesions can occur during invasive laryngeal procedures, such as intubation. 
They have a high recurrence rate and very low potential for malignancy. Adult-onset laryngeal papillomatosis is less common and usually seen in males aged 30-50 years. 
It is less aggressive and involves the anterior part of the vocal cords. The treatment is the same as 
juvenile papillomatosis. Patients present with hoarseness, aphonia, dyspnea, or stridor. Laryngoscopy shows pinkish to 
white grape-like projections that can be sessile or pedunculate with a visible central vascular 
core. The diagnosis is confirmed by direct laryngoscopy and biopsy. Treatment consists 
of micro-laryngoscopy and CO2 laser excision. The image below depicts laryngeal papillomatosis on laryngoscopy: Reinke's edema (Option A) is a collection of fluid in the subepithelial space of Reinke. It generally 
occurs in patients with vocal abuse or smoking. The vocal cords will show diffuse, symmetrical 
swelling. The laryngoscopic image below shows Reinke's edema: 539 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 12: A 5 year old with gradually progressive hoarseness of voice over three months and respiratory 
distress for 2 weeks. Diagnosis is

options.b: Vocal cords fail to adduct on phonation but adduct during coughing
options.c: Aphonia is sudden and unaccompanied by laryngeal symptoms
options.d: Treatment includes reassurance of this patient

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario of a child presenting with chronic hoarseness (3 months) of voice and 
respiratory distress for 2 weeks suggests the diagnosis of respiratory papillomatosis (juvenile 
papillomatosis). Croup (Option A) and acute epiglottitis (Option D), which cause acute upper respiratory tract 
obstruction, are ruled out due to the chronic nature of the symptoms. In croup, the upper airway 
obstruction becomes apparent after 1 to 3 days of low-grade fever, rhinorrhea, and pharyngitis. On 
the other hand, in epiglottitis, a child experiences respiratory distress within hours of developing 
a fever. Vocal nodules (Option C) are not typically associated with respiratory distress. Respiratory papillomatosis is the most common respiratory tract neoplasm in children. They are 
simple warts (benign tumors) caused by human papillomavirus types 6 and 11 commonly seen in 
children aged 3 to 5 years. The course involves remissions and exacerbations of recurrent papillomas, mostly affecting the 
glottic area (vocal cords), and supraglottis. The patient presents with progressively worsening 
hoarseness, sleep-disordered breathing, dyspnea, stridor, and severe airway obstruction if left 
untreated. Diagnosis confirmed by direct laryngoscopy, which shows grape-like projections (shown below), 
and biopsy. Treatment consists of micro laryngoscopy and CO2 laser excision. Antivirals like 
interferon alpha2a, ribavirin, cidofovir, and acyclovir are used as adjunct therapies. 540 
Sold by @itachibot Other options: Option A: Croup (laryngotracheobronchitis) is caused by the parainfluenza virus. The patient 
initially presents with an upper respiratory tract infection (rhinorrhea, pharyngitis, cough, 
low-grade fever) followed by a characteristic barking cough, hoarseness, and inspiratory stridor. Option C: Vocal nodule (singer’s or screamer's nodule) occurs as a result of chronic vocal abuse. 
They appear symmetrically at the junction of the anterior one-third and posterior two third of the 
vocal cord. The patient presents with chronic hoarseness and voice fatigue. The image below shows symmetric vocal nodules: Option D: Acute epiglottitis is caused by streptococcus pyogenes, pneumococci, Hemophilus 
influenzae, and staphylococcus aureus. It is characterized by an acute rapidly progressive course 
of high-grade fever, dyspnea, and stridor. 541 
Sold by @itachibot Voice and Speech Disorders
